stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes a redesigned entrance to Course 4 (the zoo / “Wario’s Wildlife World”) from the overworld. He abandons an over-complicated ticket/penguin concept, builds a crawlspace-based gate bypass with strong visual telegraphing (coins/mice), and implements a Wario “goalkeeper” NPC that physically blocks jumping around the gate until the player has entered the zoo once. While wiring the one-time gating logic, he discovers and fixes an engine bug where cutscene flags were written to the wrong course index (mirroring a known vanilla SM64 cannon-flag bug).
stream_context.significance_reason: A concrete overworld progression mechanic is designed and implemented (crawlspace + Wario blocker + one-time unlock), and a non-trivial engine bug is uncovered/fixed involving cutscene flag bookkeeping across levels.

findings.summary: Kaze decides the original zoo-entry plan (Wario charging “your coins + 1” plus catching a penguin for a ticket) is too random and inelegant, and pivots to a simpler, more readable mechanic centered on a crawlspace bypass near the main gate.

The new plan: the main gate is the “obvious” entrance, but access is actually via a side tunnel/crawlspace; Wario stands at/near the gate and blocks attempts to jump over or slip around it until the player has legitimately entered the zoo once.

Kaze explicitly worries about tutorialization/readability: crawlspaces are used elsewhere, but he still wants strong telegraphing (coin trail into the hole, possibly mice entering/exiting) to reduce the risk that players won’t think to crawl.

He’s willing to leave an advanced movement bypass for speedrunners (e.g., high-velocity tricks to enter without crawling), and even likes the idea—though he plans to reduce the extreme velocity gain that currently makes it “stupid” easy.

While implementing “Wario disappears after you’ve entered the zoo once,” Kaze discovers an engine bug: during cutscenes, the game wrote the cutscene flag to the wrong course/slot in save flags, preventing the correct ‘visited’ state from being set.

He notes the bug parallels a classic vanilla SM64 issue where opening a cannon in Bob-omb Battlefield can set the cannon-open flag for Womp’s Fortress—suggesting the root cause is shared: incorrect indexing into level state during certain contexts (cutscenes / last-level-in-RAM edge cases).

Wario’s blocker behavior needed collision-safe movement: he could push Mario into walls or get stuck “in jail” by rubbing against boundaries. Kaze mitigates this by changing the constraint logic (home/position checks) and counteracting wall push-off so Wario stays centered on his blocking line.

Kaze reiterates there’s an active engine/collision issue where the player can occasionally phase through geometry. He frames collision correctness as one of the hardest problems and flags it as a priority to fix (especially to prevent players clipping through the game).

He gives a status update on remaining engine rework work: after the “operating system” work and a collision BVH (broad-phase) are finished, he expects to be “finally free” to focus primarily on making game content.
findings.quote: The only engine rework stuff that is now left is the operating system and collision BVH, and then finally free we can go on to just make my game.

findings.summary: Content scale/performance pressure shows up: the zoo level model is already ~29,000 triangles before final collision is added, reinforcing ongoing constraints of N64-era budgets even in a decomp-based project.

Kaze discusses collaboration dynamics: in his observation, collabs often slow progress and can “turn sour,” implying he prefers a controlled core-team pipeline over frequent external collabs for a long project like RTYI.

A prolonged personal tangent reveals ongoing anxiety about self-employment taxes despite believing he filed correctly; he connects increased anxiety to having a child and feeling pressure to be a “proper civilian,” and he notices it harming his ability to think/debug in the moment.

Kaze strongly dislikes cosmetics-as-rewards in games (citing Tears of the Kingdom and some Pokémon titles) and says he doesn’t want that design pattern in his own work unless it’s optional/out-of-the-way or tied to meaningful gameplay changes.
findings.quote: I hate cosmetics in video games.

biobak.summary: Kaze expects Biobak to rework the overworld/zoo entrance visuals later, so Kaze focuses now on proving the gameplay flow and gating logic.

Kaze credits Biobak as the one who makes/extends Wario’s move set/animations (Kaze references Biobak enabling “more and more of Wario’s moves”), which matters because the gate-blocking concept depends on responsive animations (jump/block/shuffle).

findings.summary: Kaze reports Sauraen pushed an F3DEX3 update that yields roughly a ~100–200 microsecond RSP performance improvement; Kaze frames it as small but meaningful headroom.

key_stories.title: Replacing an overcomplicated zoo entry with a crawlspace + Wario gatekeeper
key_stories.summary: Kaze realizes the planned entry sequence (coin-extortion gag + penguin ticket fetch quest) is too convoluted for an overworld gate. He pivots to a simpler, more legible solution: a visible main gate that’s blocked by Wario, plus a side crawlspace tunnel as the real entry path, with optional speedrunner bypasses.
key_stories.challenge: Designing a progression gate into the zoo that feels intuitive, diegetic, and not ‘random,’ while still giving coins and overworld NPCs a purpose.
key_stories.process: He critiques the ticket/penguin concept as inelegant, researches real zoo entrance patterns, and prototypes a new layout: main gate + side tunnel. He plans telegraphing (coin trail, mice) and adds Wario as an active blocker so jumping over walls isn’t the dominant solution.
key_stories.outcome: A playable prototype exists: the warp transition into the zoo works, the crawlspace route is visible, and Wario blocks most straightforward bypass attempts; future polish includes signage (‘Wario’s Wildlife World’) and better crawlspace readability.
key_stories.key_quote: We only care about the gameplay mechanic to actually get into the zoo.

key_stories.title: Cutscene-flag save bug discovered via Wario despawn logic
key_stories.summary: While trying to make Wario disappear after the player has entered the zoo once, Kaze finds that the ‘visited’ state isn’t being recorded. The root cause is an engine bug where cutscene flags were written to the wrong course index—an issue with echoes in vanilla SM64’s mis-indexed cannon flags.
key_stories.challenge: Implementing one-time gating (‘block until you’ve visited’) required reliable persistence of a ‘watched intro cutscene / entered level’ flag.
key_stories.process: He tests the flow (enter zoo, watch intro, die, return) and finds Wario still present. He traces the save flag type/slot (U8 vs S16 concerns) and realizes the cutscene flag is being set in the wrong place; he compares it to SM64’s known cross-level cannon flag bug.
key_stories.outcome: He fixes the indexing, retests, and confirms Wario now disappears after the first legitimate entry—unlocking the intended quality-of-life behavior.

key_stories.title: Making Wario a ‘goalkeeper’ without collision jank
key_stories.summary: The gatekeeper concept required Wario to physically intercept Mario, but early behavior could clip Mario into walls or cause Wario to drift/stick due to wall push-off. Kaze adjusts the movement constraints to keep Wario centered and prevent the worst clipping cases.
key_stories.challenge: A moving blocker NPC near tight geometry can create frustrating softlocks (player stuck) or unintended exploits (clipping past).
key_stories.process: He observes failure modes (‘in jail,’ clipping into wall), changes axis/constraint checks, and modifies the logic so wall collision doesn’t push Wario off his intended track. He also considers enlarging Wario’s hitbox on Y to guarantee blocking.
key_stories.outcome: Blocking becomes consistent and clipping is “no more possible” in his test setup; remaining work includes adding a shuffle animation and refining how Wario recenters when Mario is far away.
key_stories.key_quote: I love how annoying he is.

open_questions.topic: Final intended player onboarding for crawlspaces at the overworld scale
open_questions.context: Kaze believes players will ‘figure it out,’ but still debates whether a visual indicator is necessary, and suggests coins/mice as affordances.
questions: Where is the very first crawlspace in RTYI that you expect most players to encounter, and what did you learn from testing whether they understood crouch/crawl?
What exact telegraphing ended up shipping for the zoo tunnel (coin trail length, mice, lighting, camera framing), and did you iterate based on confusion reports?
Did you ever consider adding an explicit hint (dialogue, sign, or journal) and reject it—what made that feel like ‘overkill’?

open_questions.topic: The cutscene-flag indexing bug and its broader impact on progression
open_questions.context: Kaze found the cutscene flag was being written to the wrong save slot/course index during cutscenes, similar to vanilla SM64 cannon flag issues.
questions: How did you ultimately diagnose the flag being written to the wrong course—was it a struct layout issue, a ‘current level’ pointer changing during cutscenes, or an off-by-one/course-index mapping bug?
What other systems might have been silently wrong because of this (stars collected, one-time events, NPC state), and did you audit anything after fixing it?
Do you have a regression test approach for save flags now, given how easy it is for N64-era indexing bugs to hide?

open_questions.topic: Design stance on speedrunner bypasses vs. intended gating
open_questions.context: Kaze is open to advanced-tech bypasses (high velocity gains) letting players enter the zoo without crawling, but also says current velocity gain is ‘dumb’ and needs dialing back.
questions: What’s your philosophy for RTYI: do you intentionally preserve a ‘speedrunner layer’ of movement tech even when it undermines gating, or do you only allow bypasses that are sufficiently difficult?
How do you decide when a bypass is a fun secret versus a bug that will ‘make you sad’ because it breaks the game?
Did you end up nerfing the specific velocity gain shown here, and if so, how did you keep movement feeling good while removing the exploit?

open_questions.topic: Engine roadmap: collision BVH as a prerequisite for smarter NPCs (Mario AI)
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions wanting a Mario AI but needing collision BVH first so training/inference is fast enough on real hardware.
questions: What does ‘Mario AI’ mean in RTYI—an adversary, a simulation in the zoo narrative, or a background actor in the overworld?
How exactly does the collision BVH unlock this—are you doing on-device training, faster rollout evaluation, or simply making pathfinding feasible in real time?
Did the AI idea survive once BVH work progressed, or did it get cut for scope/performance reasons?
